title: M.V.I. (Mudular Virus Interface)
historical_context: This article presents a theoretical framework for a new type of modular virus that could infect various binary files on a system, reflecting the hacker culture's ongoing exploration of malware development during the early 1990s.
short_summary: The article discusses a theoretical framework for a modular virus interface (MVI) that could allow a virus to infect all binary files on a hard drive. It outlines the architecture of the virus and its components, including a 'Mother' module that manages the infection process.
summary:
In 'M.V.I. (Mudular Virus Interface)', Bumblebee/29a introduces a conceptual model for a new type of virus capable of infecting all binary files on a hard drive. The core idea revolves around a 'Mother' module that patches the Windows kernel and hooks into system calls to monitor file operations. When a file with a specific signature is detected, the Mother module loads the corresponding virus module into memory, allowing it to execute its payload. This approach emphasizes the potential for viruses to operate in a stealthy manner, leveraging existing system functions to propagate and execute without detection.

The article delves into the technical specifications of the virus format, detailing how the Mother module interacts with the operating system and manages the execution of various virus modules. It outlines the necessary components for a functional virus, including imports and hooks, and provides a sample code snippet to illustrate how a minimal virus could be structured. While the article is theoretical and does not provide a complete implementation, it serves as a thought-provoking exploration of modular virus design, highlighting the need for antivirus solutions to adapt to evolving threats in the malware landscape.
